question: She's still sinking... Gone.
answer: We're here to stay.

question: Well? Where are we? Have any notion, skipper?
answer: We're some three hundred and twenty light years from Earth. On an unnamed planet in orbit around a star in the constellation of Orion. That could be Bellatrix.

question: The question, Landon, is not so much where we are as when we are.
answer: We've had a nice snooze. Let's start earning all our back pay. Take your soil test, Dodge. I'll check the equipment. Got your sensors?

question: Yo!
answer: Geiger counter?

question: Yo!
answer: One pistol... twenty-four rounds of ammo. two medical kits.. one camera... one TX9. We've enough food and water for three days.

question: But how long is a day?
answer: Good question. Landon -- check your communications kit. Landon! Join the expedition.

question: Good question. Landon -- check your communications kit. Landon! Join the expedition.
answer: Sorry... I was thinking of Stewart. What d'you suppose happened?

question: Air leak. Died in her sleep.
answer: You don't seem very cut up about it.

question: It's a little late for a wake. She's been dead nearly a year.
answer: Then we've been away from Earth for eighteen months.

question: By our time. You've turned gray. Apart from that, you look pretty chipper for a man who's two thousand and thirty one years old. I read the clocks. They bear out Hasslein's hypothesis. We've been away from Earth for two thousand years, give or take a decade. Still can't accept it, huh?
answer: long pause) You know it.

question: Because time has wiped out everyone and everything you cared for -- they're dust.
answer: Prove it. If we can't get back, it's still just a theory.

question: It's a fact, Landon. Buy it. You'll sleep better.
answer: Nothing will grow here .... there's just a trace of hydrocarbons, and most of the nitrogen is locked into nitrates.

question: Any sign of dangerous ionization?
answer: No.

question: Okay. If there's no life here, we've got just seventy-two hours to find it. That's when the groceries run out.
answer: Which direction?

question: That way.
answer: Any particular reason?

question: None at all. Everybody all right? Water check.
answer: Eight ounces. It doesn't add up. There's a mantle of dust around this planet and yet it's as humid as a jungle. Thunder and lightning and yet no rain. Cloud cover every night and that strange luminosity, and yet no moon.

question: You're more than three hundred light years from your precious planet. Your loved ones have been dead and forgotten for twenty centuries. Even if you could get back, they'd think you were something that fell out of a tree.
answer: All right --

question: There's only one reality left. We're here and it's now. You get ahold of that and hang on tight, or you might as well be dead.
answer: I'm prepared to die.

question: He's prepared to die! Doesn't that make you misty? Chalk up another victory for the human spirit! Straighten me out on something. Why did you come along at all? You volunteered. Why? I'll tell you. They nominated you for the Big One and you couldn't turn it down. Not without losing your All-American standing
answer: Climb off me, will you!

question: And the glory, don't forget that. There's a life-sized bronze statue of you somewhere. It's probably turned green by now, and nobody can read the name plate. But never let it be said we forget our heroes.
answer: Taylor. I'm telling you --

question: Oh, and one last item. Immortality. You wanted to go on forever. Well, you damn near made it. Except for Dodge and me, you've lived longer than anybody. And with Stewart dead, it looks like we're the last of the strain. You got what you wanted, kid. How does it taste?
answer: Okay. You read me well enough. Why can't I read you?

question: Don't bother
answer: Dodge ... he's not like me at all. But he makes sense. Held walk naked into a live volcano if he thought he could learn something no other man knew. I understand why he's here. But you...You're no seeker. You're negative.

question: But I'm not prepared to die.
answer: I'd like to know why not. You thought life on Earth was meaningless. You despised people. So what did you do? You ran away.

question: Which one was wearing the strange clothes?
answer: Him.

question: Will he live?
answer: I don't know. This beast lost a lot of blood. There's no probe here. Find one!

question: This place is dirty, doctor.
answer: These animals are dirty, doctor. They stink, and they carry communicable diseases. Why aren't they cleaned up before they're brought here?

question: But the quota system's been abolished! You made it. Why can't I?
answer: What do you mean, made it? I'm an animal psychologist, that's all. We don't have any authority.

question: You do pretty well when it comes to getting space and equipment.
answer: That's because Dr. Zaius realizes our work has value.

question: Hmph.
answer: The foundations of scientific brain surgery are being laid right here - in studies of cerebral function in these animals.

question: Simmer down! You especially. Better give it a try, stupid. Unless you like going hungry. Good morning, Dr. Zira.
answer: Good morning, Julius. How's our patient today?

question: No change. The minute you open the door, he goes into his act.
answer: Well, what do we want this morning? Do we want something? Speak! Come on, speak! Do we want some sugar, old-timer?

question: You could get hurt doing that, Doctor.
answer: Don't be silly. He's perfectly tame.

question: They're all tame until they take a chunk out of you.
answer: Well, Bright Eyes, is our throat feeling better?

question: Did you see that? It's remarkable!
answer: Huh?

question: He's trying to form words.
answer: Well, you know what they say. Human see, human do. Now what?

question: He seems to want something.
answer: I'd be careful, doctor. What did I tell you! Try that again, I'll break your arm!

question: Put her in with him.
answer: Do you have to work tonight?

question: No.
answer: Neither do I.

question: That's Bright Eyes. The one I was telling you about.
answer: What's so special about him?

question: Watch. Hello, Bright Eyes. How's our throat today? Look -- she remembers.
answer: Remembers what?

question: The blood transfusion.
answer: Zira, come on. You know they can't -- Oh oh. Here comes Number One.

question: What happened?
answer: Those fools and their torches! Do you have any ointment?

question: I'll see.
answer: I'm sorry, Bright Eyes.

question: I told you what you'd get!
answer: Julius, don't. It doesn't matter.

question: Natural born thieves, aren't they?
answer: Get me a collar and leash. I'm taking him to the infirmary.

question: He's vicious, Doctor. Besides, it's against the rules.
answer: Do as I say. You wouldn't hurt me, would you... Taylor?

question: Do as I say. You wouldn't hurt me, would you... Taylor?
answer: It's a stunt. Humans don't write.

question: Dear, you're a scientist. Don't you believe your own eyes?
answer: Where did you learn to do this? Jefferson Public School, Fort Wayne, Indiana? Back on that planet you say you came from? Um-hm. He may be intelligent, but he's also mad.

question: 'And you're a fool'.
answer: Now, just a minute --

question: Oh, Cornelius, be quiet. 'Dodge was killed in the hunt. What happened to Landon?' I don't know.
answer: And they fell out of the sky with you?

question: 'Not fell -- flew!'
answer: Flight is a scientific impossibility.

question: And even if it weren't, why fly? Where would it get you?
answer: Well, now...

question: 'Do you have maps?'
answer: We are here ... You were captured about here.

question: You fell in the water here? ... you came ashore ... you marched across the desert ... the mountains ... many days and nights ... and reached the jungle.
answer: Out - of - the - question!.

question: Cornelius, why do you insist on provoking him?
answer: No creature can survive in that part of the Forbidden Zone. I've been there. I've seen it.

question: 'Then how do you account for me?,
answer: I don't. And I'm not going to try.

question: But what about your theory? The existence of someone like Taylor might prove it.
answer: Zira, are you trying to get my head cut off?

question: Don't be foolish. If it's true, they'll have to accept it.
answer: No, they won't -

question: Cornelius has developed a brilliant hypothesis -
answer: It's probably wrong --

question: -- that the ape evolved from a lower order of primate, possibly man. In his trip to the Forbidden Zone he discovered traces of a culture older than recorded time -
answer: The evidence was very meager --

question: You didn't think so then.
answer: That was before Dr. Zaius and half the Academy said the idea was heresy.

question: How can scientific truth be heresy? What if Taylor is exactly the proof you needed? A mutation. A missing link between the unevolved primate and the ape -
answer: He's touchy, isn't he?

question: 'I am not a missing link.'
answer: Because if he is a missing link, it means the Sacred Scrolls aren't worth their parchment.

question: Well, maybe they're not.
answer: No, thank you'. I won't get into that battle.

question: Oh, Cornelius, show some strength!
answer: Zira, listen to me. We've got a fine future ahead of us. Marriage. Stimulating careers. I'm up for a raise -- Dr. Zaius --

question: Zira, listen to me. We've got a fine future ahead of us. Marriage. Stimulating careers. I'm up for a raise -- Dr. Zaius --
answer: Did you forget our appointment, Cornelius?

question: Oh., no., sir. I was just assembling my notes.
answer: You know Dr. Maximus, our Commissioner for Animal Affairs?

question: What is that?
answer: A man, Dr. Maximus.

question: I know it's a man. And you know the rules. No animals outside the compound, and most certainly not without a leash.
answer: Yes, Sir. But this -- creature is a special case.

question: Why special?
answer: We're -- conducting a new experiment.

question: Get away from me, you dirty ape! ...and that's when I decided to take up astronautical engineering., you see. I was halfway through college and I... It's an old trick! The silent treatment. Four weeks and three days, and not a word from anyone. Not Zira.,or Cornelius...or that damn Julius. No one'll listen... only you. You...Nova. NO-VAH. Yeah...me Tarzan, you Jane. That's all right ... I had a puppy once that never barked. He just licked my hand. He's dead now. They're all dead. Everything... I think maybe they'll kill me, too. Are they afraid of me? I can't hurt them... but I threaten them somehow. Threaten their faith in simian superiority. Yeah ... you're right. They'll have to kill me. Let her alone! Where are you taking her? What are you going to do? Take your hands off her, you black monster! You filth! Why are you doing this? Say something, you hairy scum!
answer: Turn it off!

question: Answer me!
answer: Shut up! The reason no one'll talk to you is because you're a freak!

question: Where's Dr. Zira? Why--?
answer: I said shut up!

question: By your leave, Mr. President -- the Tribunal has not yet defined the purpose of this inquiry.
answer: You asked for the opportunity to present your case. Surely you must know why you're here.

question: My own purpose is to save this exceptional creature from mutilation.
answer: And our purpose is to settle custodial and jurisdictional questions concerning this beast, and determine what's to be done with him.

question: Then I'll defend myself.
answer: Dr. Zira -- tell Bright Eyes to sit down.

question: My name is Taylor.
answer: It says here that his name is Bright Eyes. You gave him that name yourself.

question: This hearing is absurd! Let me tell my story...
answer: Bailiff! Make the animal be quiet. State your case, Mr. Prosecutor.

question: Tell the court, Bright Eyes -- what is the second Article of Faith?
answer: I admit, I know nothing of your culture.

question: Of course he doesn't know our culture - because he cannot think. Tell us why all apes are created equal.
answer: Some apes, it seems, are more equal than others.

question: Ridiculous. That answer is a contradiction in terms. Tell us, Bright Eyes, why do men have no souls? What is the proof that a divine spark exists in the simian brain?
answer: Show this to the President.

question: Since the defendant is forbidden to speak in his own defense, he asks that this statement be read into the record.
answer: Read it yourself.

question: 'I have come to you from a planet in a different solar system. I am an explorer in space, with no hostile intentions against your civilization. On my planet it was the primate Man who evolved Into a thinking animal, while the apes remained..."
answer: Stop right there. Bring me that paper. This is a joke in very poor taste.

question: Is it a joke to seek the truth about this man?
answer: Dr. Zira -- you state here that a ship from outer space sank in an inland sea of our eastern desert.

question: I do not state it, sir. The prisoner does.
answer: Do you believe him?

question: Like you, I find it difficult.
answer: But how convenient that the proof of his arrival has vanished? You also state that Bright Eyes had two intelligent companions at the time of his capture.

question: This is his assertion.
answer: Where are they now?

question: Second from the left.
answer: Well...do you acknowledge kinship with any of these creatures?

question: With one of them.
answer: Identify him, then. Speak to him.

question: Wait outside. The verdict is in. At the moment your simian friends -- and sponsors -- are free on bail. But they'll soon be brought to trial for heresy.
answer: What about me?

question: Oh, your case was preordained. In a way, you performed a service for the State ... Because your hearing made it possible for us to expose Zira and Cornelius. And now the Tribunal has placed you in my custody for...final disposition. Do you know what that means?
answer: No.

question: Emasculation, to begin with. Then experimental surgery. On the speech centers. On the brain. Ultimately, a kind of living death. However, it's within my power to grant You a reprieve. That is why I summoned you here tonight. Tell me who and what you really are and where you come from, and no veterinary will touch you.
answer: I told the truth at that 'hearing'of yours.

question: You lied. Where is your tribe?
answer: My tribe, as you call it, lives on another planet in a distant solar system.

question: Then how is it we speak the same language? Even in your lies, some truth slips through! That mythical community you're supposed to come from -- Fort Wayne'?
answer: What about it?

question: A fort! Unconsciously, you chose a name that was belligerent. Where were you nurtured?
answer: I take it you don't believe the prosecutor's charge -- that I'm a monster created by Dr. Zira.

question: Certainly not. You're a mutant.
answer: That's exactly what Zira and Cornelius claim. You're talking heresy, doctor.

question: Of course.
answer: All right, suppose I am a mutant? Why does the appearance of one mutant send you into a panic?

question: Because you're not unique. There was the one you call Landon --
answer: Then you admit --

question: I admit that where there's one mutant there's probably another. And another. A nest of them. Where's your nest, Taylor? Where are your women?
answer: Thank you for calling me Taylor. Dr. Zaius, I know who I am. Who are you? How did this upside down civilization ever get started?

question: You may well call it upside down, since you occupy its lowest level. And deservedly. The eastern desert has never been explored -- because we've always assumed that no life can exist there. Save yourself, Taylor. Tell me -- is there another jungle beyond the Forbidden Zone?
answer: I don't know.

question: If you are protecting others of your kind, it will cost you your identity.
answer: I'm not protecting anybody! That hearing was a farce. What have I done?

question: You're a menace! A walking pestilence. I do know who you are, Taylor. As I know that others of your kind must live in the Forbidden Zone. You have just six hours to make a full confession. After that I'll employ surgery to obtain one. Guards! Take this creature back to his cage.
answer: All right, you can cut me to pieces. It's within your power. But know this, doctor. You do it because you're afraid of me. You do it from fear!

question: Are you Julius?
answer: What do you want?

question: I'm from the Office of Animal Affairs. This male's to be transferred to the zoo.
answer: At this hour? Who says so?

question: Don't they tell you anything? The Anti- vivisectionist Society is up in arms. They're going to save this beast from those butchers in the lab. If he can speak he belongs in the public zoo. But what'll probably happen is that some money-mad grown-up will put him in a circus. And then we'll have to pay to see what rightfully should have --
answer: Stop making speeches and show me the order. This order's no good. It must be counter- signed by Dr. Zaius --

question: Hit him!
answer: Who are you?

question: So you can talk. I'm Dr. Zira's nephew. This abduction was her idea. You're not really going to the zoo. That's just our cover story in case we're stopped. Although I do feel that if it ever came down to a question of whether something like you should be public or private property --
answer: Come on. Get me out of here. She comes along too.

question: Zira doesn't want your female.
answer: I want her.

question: If you insist. But I'm not taking any orders --
answer: Fine. Just let her out.

question: Taylor -- just keep quiet and we may get away with this. Remember that men all look alike to most apes.
answer: Gorilla hunters ...

question: Keep moving. We can't turn back now. You can't! I've two sick humans in the cage. We're taking them to the chief vet at the zoo ... No, no, my animals are diseased... Leave them alone! They're diseased, I tell you!
answer: Stand back! He's dangerous!

question: He's rabid! His bite is fatal!
answer: You would die in agony! Frothing at the mouth!

question: Let me out of here!
answer: Well, Taylor -- we're all fugitives now.

question: Do you have any weapons?
answer: The best. But we won't need them.

question: Just the same, I want one.
answer: Look here, Taylor. I'm in charge of this expedition --

question: Fair enough. But you're no longer in charge of me. And I don't mean to be captured again.
answer: As you wish.

question: You're going back to the Forbidden Zone?
answer: To the diggings I worked at a year ago. It's a three day ride across the eastern desert, near where you claim you landed from that planet of yours.

question: You still don't believe me, do you?
answer: It's a long detour to Dead Lake. What would we find?

question: Nothing much. The remnants of a life raft. Maybe a small flag. The emblem of my countrymen.
answer: Sorry, Taylor. The terrain around that lake is poisonous. There is no fresh water, no vegetation. Nothing.

question: Are you going to take her with you?
answer: Yes.

question: Actually, you're a different breed. This creature will never evolve.
answer: Maybe not.

question: You want her that much?
answer: You threw us together, remember? And you guessed right. Men, like apes, get despondent without a mate.

question: No. You saved me from this fanatic. Maybe I can pay you back.
answer: What is your proposal?

question: When were the Sacred Scrolls written?
answer: Twelve hundred years ago.

question: Very well. If Zira and Cornelius can prove that those scrolls don't tell the whole truth of your history; if they can show you definite evidence of another culture from an unrecorded past -- will you exonerate them?
answer: Of course.

question: Present your evidence, Cornelius.
answer: It was at this level I discovered traces of an early ape creature -- stage of primitive barbarism, really -- dating back roughly thirteen hundred years. It was here I found cutting tools and arrowheads of quartz and the fossilized bones of carnivorous gorillas. But the artifacts lying at your feet were found here, at this level. And that's the paradox. The more ancient culture is the more advanced. Admittedly, many of these objects are unidentified, but clearly they were fashioned by beings with a knowledge of metallurgy. Indeed, the very fact that these tools are unknown to us could suggest a culture in certain ways almost equal to our own. Some of the evidence is uncontestable ...

question: Don't speak to me in absolutes. The evidence is contestable.
answer: I apologize.

question: Not everything. They left a hostage. How do you feel, Lucius?
answer: Disillusioned... But vindicated! I've been right all along. You can't trust the older generation. It's a matter of values --

question: All right, all right. Will You do me a favor? No orders.
answer: What is it?

question: I want you to go around the bend and tell those gorillas their leader is my prisoner.
answer: Yes, I can do that. What if they won't agree to your terms?

question: Sit down. Over there. Now, Minister of Science - let me explain certain principle stress and strain. If you exert pressure to remove these bonds, you'll choke yourself to death. It'll be suicide, you see?
answer: Taylor, please -- don't treat him that way.

question: Why not?
answer: It's humiliating.

question: He won't survive. Do you know what sort of life awaits you out there, Taylor? That of an animal. If you aren't eventually hunted down and killed by apes, some jungle beast will devour you.
answer: Then there is another jungle?

question: Of course, you could return with us. Our society might find a place for you and your mate.
answer: Sure. In a cage.

question: Where else, but in a cage, does man belong?
answer: No, thanks. I'll take freedom. Would you like to come along?

question: God bless you. Lucius.
answer: I think you're making a mistake.

question: That's the boy. Keep 'em flying.
answer: What?

question: The flags of discontent. It's the only way anything ever gets changed. Don't try to follow us. I'm pretty handy with things like this.
answer: Of that I'm sure. All my life I've awaited your coming and dreaded it. Like death itself.

question: Why? From the first, I've terrified you, Doctor. And in spite of every sign that I'm an intelligent being who means no harm, you continue to hate and fear me. Why?
answer: Because you are a man. And you were right -- I have always known about man. From the evidence, I believe his wisdom must walk hand in hand with his idiocy. His emotions must rule his brain. He must be a warlike animal who gives battle to everything around him -- even himself.

question: What evidence? No weapons were found in the cave.
answer: The Forbidden Zone was once a paradise. Your breed made a desert of it, ages ago.

question: We're back at the beginning. I still don't know the why. A planet where apes evolved from men. A world turned wrong side up. A puzzle with one piece missing.
answer: Don't look for it, Taylor. You may not like what you find. Untie me! No, no! Let him go! Fetch your explosives. We're going to seal the cave.

question: What I do, I do with no pleasure. Silence him.
answer: Dr. Zaius, this is inexcusable! Why must knowledge stand still? What about the future?

question: I may just have saved it for you.
answer: What will he find out there, doctor?
